text: a beautiful swimming pool a
well-equipped gym clean and tidy three
to a room accommodation this is the
showcase workers complex the government
of Qatar had invited us to see after
years of criticism about their treatment
of migrant workers the Qataris want to
show they are changing not surprisingly
residents here are happy to settle any
year planning earlier subsidence or
that's aar everything is good here my
lifestyle has changed it's a better more
hygienic place to live on the other side
of town and away from our PR minders we
joined a busload of workers to see where
the majority of migrants live now many
have been here for years and endure the
long hours and lack of holiday in order
to send money back home this housing is
as good as it gets for them
we'd heard conditions elsewhere were far
worse and set off to investigate what we
didn't know is that we were being
followed by the State Security Service
our arrest was dramatic eight cars drove
us off the road as we left the center of
Doha the driver translator cameraman and
I were treated like spies and
interrogated separately by security
officers our camera and footage was
seized we were cut off from the outside
world and not allowed to make any calls
we spent two nights in a filthy prison
the intelligence officers showed us a
dossier of photos of us working and
socializing in town we had been tailed
from the moment we'd arrived in
handcuffs
we were hauled in front of a prosecutor
he accused us of disrespecting Qatar and
threatened to throw us in jail for more
nights to teach us a lesson then just as
suddenly as we've been arrested they let
us go international media coverage of
the treatment of low-skilled workers in
Qatar is a constant irritation for the
government without visa the can hours
after leaving prison
I met the Labour Minister who had
actually invited us to the country I
asked him whether the security services
were being overly paranoid I am more
paranoid than their I am facing it day
in and day out
morning and evening sometimes I wake up
at night I open one of those
international TV channels and there is a
party executing workers in the street I
mean the figures that we have whatever
small it is it is too much too much but
it is by far list what has been reported
in international press Amnesty
International's expert on Qatar is
worried by the direction in which some
sections of the government are heading
10 minutes after the last time we met we
were arrested in Doha do you think this
is part of a crackdown on the media I
think it's certainly a case of
intimidating media trying to expose a
situation for migrant labour in Qatar
that's a serious concern
it's not the first time as you know it
happened to a German film crew we know
activists also being very fearful now in
the country you know the best way for
Qatar to address violent labor abuse is
to stop it not to stop media trying to
report on it as Qatar's World Cup
approaches the focus on migrant labor is
only likely to increase how this country
handles the media is it prepares to host
one of the world's most watched sporting
events is now becoming a concern
mark Lobo BBC News
